data.title: TouchScreenButton + no CanvasLayer + stretch aspect
data.body: Add a TouchScreenButton to a regular 2D node so that it's not part of a new CanvasLayer, and it'll respond incorrectly to touches when a stretch aspect setting is applied.  In my case, the touchscreen is wider than my project settings, so the button responds to a touch to its left, and doesn't respond to touches that are actually on it.

data.title: Particles2D change mask submenu location
data.body:
I think it's more intuitive to have the Particles Mask menu inside the inspector with the rest of the properties.
I've been looking for a "mask" property for an hour. I even looked inside the .xml file in the Particles2d demo project. There's where I found the Vector2Array of positions.

That's it, I think its more user friendly.

data.title: Keep object child transform information intact when re-parenting
data.body:
## Currently

Re-parenting an object in the node tree will often send the newly minted child somewhere else in the level, requiring the user to find it and move it back to where it is needed.
## Proposal

Change the operation so it doesn't change the transform values of the new child object at all (the object stays exactly where it was placed).
## Benefits

It will make it much easier to reorganize parent/child hierarchies as the desired setup remains intact as nodes are moved around. Saving time and reducing frustration.

I hope this is seen as a good suggestion for the 1.2 usability release.

Thanks.

data.title: Support parenting setups in Collada I/O
data.body:
## Currently

Godot will import the parent object, but discard the child object. This might be due to a lack of support of the import of object parenting setups in both the _better collada exporter_ and Godot's importer.
## Proposal

Support all forms of parent/child relationships in both the exporter and the importer (and have the generated nodes resemble that setup as seen in the 3D application)
## Benefits

It will make it a lot easier to create things like unique moving platforms (made just for a certain level), make it easier to create level-specific objects and allow one to increase the amount of level building work in the 3D application

I hope adding this will be seen as useful

Thanks.

data.title: Bitmask editor and some CanvasItem documentation.
data.body:
I've added the keyword FLAGS to the int hint to allow the editor to edit an int as a bitmask.
I also added some documentation about the arg4 argument of the CanvasItem::draw_texture_rect*.

data.title: Scene file breaking bug when not saving a GDScript resource
data.body:
**After a while I've noticed that my disk was full, that's why the save was corrupted. Anyway GODOT tried to save and didn't report an error, so I guess this is a bug anyway. Leaving old description here just for the sake...**

So I just got my test scene wrecked by this bug, and since I didn't use GIT or anything.. RIP work :D (maybe use temp .scn files for recovery in the future?)

Anyway, tl;dr - ~~if you add a GDScript resource and not save it, but you save the scene it basically corrupts the scene [1.1stable]~~ (insufficent disk space was the cause of this, GODOT didn't notify about it)

Reporduction:
1. Create a new scene
2. Create a main node of somekind (doesn't matter which class)
3. Go to Resources tab, add a resource of type GDScript
4. Write something in the code editor, for example `extends Node`
5. Click around the editor, or wait a couple of seconds, the editor's tab name turns into `(*)` which suggests an unexpected behaviour
6. CTRL+S saves the scene instead of the GDScript file, which is counter-intuitive, anyway save the scene
7. Try to load the just-saved scene (or load another one and try to load this scene again)
8. Ooops! `Error loading scene`

~~Result: Scene file is corrupted, overwriting previous work on the scene
Binary-wise the file has a bit of junk, that's it (a few bytes maybe, truncating the scene completely).~~

What I was trying to achieve while finding this bug:
I wanted to create a GDScript that was not attached to a node right away. I've created a resource, but then I changed my mind so I removed it quickly. I couldnt close the editor's tab (another bug) so I just thought it's a little bug and decided to save the scene and reload the editor.

**EDIT: in short - GODOT doesn't detect full disk space (errors while saving a scene)**

data.title: Scene stopped with a bad number of arguments
data.body:
On Linux:

``` GDScript
class A:
    func _init(a):
        pass

var a = A.new() # scene stopped without error message
```

data.title: RFC: Fix reference check in debug marshaller
data.body:
In the GDScript debugger, the value of a variable is often printed as zero when it is actually a valid reference to an object.  This appears to be a problem in the remote script debugger.  When a variant is created from an object, the object pointer in the ObjData is initialized, but not the RefPtr.  When the variant is passed across the debugging connection, the remote debugger checks to see if it has a valid reference.  Since there is no reference, it does not retrieve the ObjectID from the object pointer to pass to the GDScript debugger, instead passing "0".

When I simply remove the RefPtr check in this patch, the ObjectID appears in the GDScript debugger as expected.  The safe_get_instance_id function is only used for the purpose of marshalling objects across the debugging connection, so there doesn't seem to be any harm in removing this check.  Is there a reason for this check that I am missing?  Is it OK to just remove this?

This "fix" corrects the seeming null reference issue reported in #2275.  In this case, find_node returns a Node pointer.  The binding code creates a variant from the Object pointer, which the remote debugger then reports as 0 instead of the Node's ObjectID.

data.title: find_node not functional
data.body:
find_node from GDScript does not seem to work as intended.  The first issue is that the find_node binding seems to include a copy/paste error in node.cpp:1842, binding to get_node instead of find_node.

The second issue is a little harder.  When I debug the engine in gdb while stepping over the find_node call, I can see the recursion search for and find a matching node, and return a pointer to the node.  The pointer seems valid until it is returned and assigned to the Variant type in the language binding, and then I don't know enough to continue following.  However, after the GDScript step-over is complete for the find_node call, the godot debugger shows the return of find_node as 0.

I have created an example project that demonstrates this.  To reproduce:
1. Set a breakpoint on the GDscript find_node call, test.gd:9.  Run the project.
2. Attach GDB to the child process.
3. Set a breakpoint on Node::find_node and continue GDB.
4. Press step-over in the godot debugger.
5. Once the GDB breakpoint is hit, step though the until the first recursion returns the matching node, to see that it is found.
6. Continue GDB so that the Godot debugger step can continue.
7. Examine the returned value in the editor; it is zero.

http://fazjaxton.net/files/test3.zip

data.title: Hardware cursor replacement is broken
data.body:
As described [here](http://www.godotengine.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=11&t=1093), hardware cursor replacement doesn't work.

The example provided by gordonfranz in the above forum post:

``` gdscript
var image = Image()
image.load("res://cursor/cursor1.png")
VisualServer.cursor_set_texture(VisualServer.texture_create_from_image(image), Vector2(), 0)
```

This should replace the cursor, but it appears to do nothing.

I'm currently doing some work on bringing a point and click adventure game to godot and ideally I would use this method for adjusting the cursor.

data.title: A "Make Resources Uniques" that applies to children nodes ; make it clearer when resources are linked
data.body:
right now, if there is a node with children nodes that you duplicate, you have to go in each node and click each time "Make Resources Uniques" in order for every resources everywhere to become unique. It can be bothersome and long process if you want to create several elements that are nearly the same but just change a little thing each time. It would be beneficient to have like an option like "Make Resources Uniques (Also in Subnodes)".
Also, it can become very unclear with time which resources are shared across which nodes. It could be cool if there was somehow a more convenient approach to know that.

data.title: Godot 1.1 crashing on startup (Win7 32bit)
data.body:
When I try to execute `godot_win32-1.1.stable.exe`, the application crash, showing the message: **"godot_win32-1.1.stable.exe has stopped working"**

In the console (which is opened when executing the .exe file), the next entries are displayed:

```
EXEC PATHP: C:\Workpace\godot_win32-1.1.stable.exe
EXEC PATHP: C:\Workpace\godot_win32-1.1.stable.exe
DETECTED MONITORS: 1
```

The PC specs are the following:

```
OS: Windows 7 Professional SP1
Processor: Pentium Dual-Core E5800 3.20GHz
Video Adapter: Intel(R) G41 Express Chipset
```
